source.text: NEWS: 'Emergency Emergency' was the final distress call that was sent from the cockpit of flight #4U9525  - @PollyR_Aviation
source.label: false

replies.text: @airlivenet @PollyR_Aviation @crislomb Looks terribly off course on a map. Nothing earlier? Like much earlier?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @PascalSyn @larsst plus af447 was exceptionnal weather conditions
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @damienramage With iced sensors it won't level off. Apparently a computer glitch - pilot would need to override system manually
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet immediately manual (autopilot off), throttle, oxygen masks + passngrs, radio call. All that in 20 seconds? #4U9525
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @PascalSyn GW flight had same descent rate as near crash LH flight. Check https://t.co/m2UVxkJqyC or https://t.co/3jPBYgeqqA
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage I've seen friends with nasal oxygen masks on (General Avation), just to fly over the Channel :) http://t.co/nVB4NILrCx
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet No, then you would say PANPAN. Trust me, I'm a pilot! Besides: Mayday is when lives are in danger...
replies.label: deny

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet Normal descend rate for A320 is 2500fpm. Now 4000fpm (for 8 minutes) which is much, but contrallable. #u4u9525
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage radio call to passengers: not a priority at all !!
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet From Airbus FlightOps: When the cabin altitude rises above 14 000 feet, the oxygen masks will deploy automatically
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @airlivenet @PollyR_Aviation So sad...prayers to the families and friends...
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet true...
replies.label: support

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet it’s a scale. Emergency < Mayday
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet radio call then passengers, no ? 20 sec isn’t much… it takes me longer to tweet sometimes ;-)
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet or think you do ? or it hasn’t been assessed ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet Plus they stayed more or less constant speed, which means they reduced throttle, so they were in control #u4u9525
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet what’s the exact procedure btw ? What altitude would you drop down to ? at which rate of descent ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet exactly. So emergency would be appropriate, for example in case of cabin decompression, right ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @PascalSyn that's just for the high
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet That would certainly explain why pilots set steap descend. Maybe they passed too quickly (oxygen masks?) #u4u9525
replies.label: comment

replies.text: “@airlivenet: NEWS: 'Emergency Emergency' was the final distress call that was sent from the cockpit of flight #4U9525  - @PollyR_Aviation”
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @damienramage @airlivenet At that altitude you have about 20 sec before you pass out. They started steep descend, reduced engine... #4U9525
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @airlivenet @PollyR_Aviation is that a normal call in this situation ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet if they had, it’s likely the descent rate would’ve been steeper and the speed not reduce, no ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @PascalSyn @airlivenet but isn’t declaring an emergency the proper procedure if you still have control of the situation ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @damienramage yes, and they have a bottle behind them with this tube connected. But it looks very stupid LOL
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @PascalSyn @damienramage @airlivenet What about icy sensors and software telling autopilot to dive as happened with AF447?

source.text: Flight #4U9525 initially climbed to 38,000 feet before before it started to descend and lost signal at 6,800 feet. http://t.co/MthXQ232Hn
source.label: unverified

replies.text: @marcepa49 the flight profile. That doesn't indicate that the autopilot was set to 100 feet. I've worked on these systems, tested them
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe That's what they say.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe It only takes a moment to enter 7700 into the transponder. I've worked on these systems before.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe distress call. I thought it was hi-jacked and being flown by then. If it's true that the co-pilot did
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Anyway. Have to wait and see now.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe crash it deliberately, the whole industry needs a shake-up.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 any idea why it'd flight so high?  It's a short flight, usually planes go at ~ 33,000 feet
replies.label: query

replies.text: @janoschjerman @flightradar24 yes and no depends on other traffic, turbulence... they were 25 mins late so going higher = going quicker
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe and have operated them in sumulators. Also on actual flights when I've been in the flight deck.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe No, somebody had just initiated the descent, and might have been unconcious or dead just after that.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Unless they became rapidly unconcious
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 But that's the FMC, doesn't mean autopilot was engaged.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: RT @flightradar24 #A320 #4U9525 initially climbed to 38k ft before starting to descend and lost signal at 6.8k ft http://t.co/LUWkDrBR9a
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe It was obvious it was being manually controlled by the changes in descent rate. Also no
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe The transponder did not say anything. No sqwak 7700.
replies.label: deny

replies.text: @marcepa49 Have you operated a flight mqnagement computer before? I used to test them. What FlightRadar24 is ahowing is changes made
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe They're saying what I said, the crash was a deliberate act. Controlled flight all the way down.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 But no emergency call made? Or emergency squawk? @isobelroe
replies.label: query

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Sent Mayday through radio. I suppose he had other things to do than adjust the Squawk
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Or autopilot. But sure deliberately set.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 Any ATC available? Strange.....
replies.label: query

replies.text: @marcepa49 It changes the flight profile and cuts out the warnings and some of the protection.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe The data from the transponder made it obvious.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe It turns out there was no distress call made. I'm almost certain this was a hi-jacking now.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 isn’t 38,000ft unusually high?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe If someone set the autopilot to fly it into the ground, the descent rate would have been constant.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe which seems to be the case.Constant descent, wind variations set aside..
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 The autopilot wasn't set to 100 feet. It was flown manually. FlightRadar24 has made that up.
replies.label: support

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe It looks like someone was flying it manually, all the way into the ground.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe They're now saying the co-pilot deliberately crashed the plane.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Look at the time on each line. The altitudes are requested not achieved.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe I don't think the autopilot was engaged.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 @marcepa49 @isobelroe What I'm saying is, I believe it was deliberately crashed. Being controlled all the way into the ground
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 @Minus777 @marcepa49 @isobelroe Yep, it's follow exactly the route going down, that seems to suggest unconscious pilots.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Would be good to get the data from the Flight Data Recorder though.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @marcepa49 @isobelroe For sure not, it was following exactly the same flight path as day before https://t.co/JoVKD5OHC0
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @flightradar24 Sounds like a decent of 2900fpm
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe What's the use when you're crashing?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @Minus777 what's the use of changing FMC if autopilot not engaged?
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Autopilot was manually changed from 38,000 to 100 ft at 09:30:55 (Flightradar24 says)
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Minus777 @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe yes but every second not spent trying to save everyone.....
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @marcepa49 @flightradar24 @isobelroe Only takes a second to set the squawk code,

source.text: 1047 call: DGAC source says pilots called «urgence, urgence» (“emergency, emergency”), as opposed to a mayday call or 7700 squawk. #4U9525
source.label: false

replies.text: @thatjohn @RunwayGirl They made that call in French?
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @1CParsons @thatjohn No 'Pan Pan' call is universal
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @thatjohn what are the implications of this? @RAeSTimR
replies.label: query

replies.text: @thatjohn is that unusual?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @thatjohn @planefinder why would they say urgence in lieu of mayday which is standard ?
replies.label: query

replies.text: @cobaltjacket @thatjohn @RunwayGirl Lots of radio protocol is French... Mayday is M'aidez. Urgence, pan-pan, "see-lonce" etc.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @thatjohn @Holbornlolz Mayday is a call for urgent assistance. (M'aidez). Not a lot of help for a plane hurtling towards the floor.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @RAeSTimR @thatjohn Ahh.. I was always taught it was a UK only thing; and having done only limited flying abroad never tested that!
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @Fedupwithclowns @thatjohn @RunwayGirl Roger. Just seems odd given most comms are in English. Doesn't make it wrong, of course.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @cobaltjacket @thatjohn @RunwayGirl Just historic. Also hard to confuse with other words, so clear for the listener.
replies.label: comment

replies.text: @thatjohn @RAeSTimR Is that roughly equivalent to our 'Pan Pan' call it priority I assume?
replies.label: support

replies.text: @thatjohn @gerrylynch mayday is French!
replies.label: comment
